posts.cooked:
I have a couple of questions.

First, I assume you are trying to get the value of a joystick in order to move a motor according to that value. Thus, I have to ask, why you are declaring a private final int. The private keyword isn’t going to do anything since I am assuming you are using it in a local scope, but the final keyword means that the value cannot be edited after the declaration. Next, I’m pretty sure the joystick would output it’s value as a decimal value between -1 and 1. As a result, the int type would be a very poor choice unless you just want -1, 0, or 1. In that case you are going to have to do some rounding or modifying to get the values that you want because of how java turns floats into ints. Anything below 1 and above -1 is going to get turned into 0.

Second, you ask for help for GenericHID, but your example says XboxController. WPILIB does have a XboxController class you can use, but it wouldn’t really change your usage.

I would advise you to look at the wpilib docs and read how to get joystick values for your use case. Joysticks — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

I would do something like this for GenericHID.

Create your controller object like so: private final GenericHID m_controller = new GenericHID(Constants.kJoystickPort);

and then where you are trying to get joystick values put this: double exampleMovement = m_controller.getRawAxis(Constants.kAxisNumber);

where Constants.kJoystickPort and Constants.kAxisNumber are whatever joystick port and axis number you are using. If you are unsure of what numbers these are, you can open driverstation with the controller plugged in and open the controllers tab to test it.

Yes the axis numbers are ints. However, I don’t think I fully understand your first statement. Do you mean that exampleMovement is for finding the controller port of the controller you want to use for swerve drive? Or is it the value you want to get from the joystick axis? You said it goes from 0 to full which doesn’t sound like a normal thumbstick on a xbox controller, it sounds more like the adjustable slider on a flight joystick.

Thanks. No, we are using the joystick for a single motor for the value of the joystick axis.

And yes it isn’t a normal thumbstick. we are making the controller on our own and it looks like this. it makes a clicky sound when you get the value and it goes from neutral to full.
I was also doing some programing stuff (copying and pasting) while looking for what looks useful. i have that part down and i’m just having issues with the joystick.

oh, that makes sense. I don’t have any experience with those types of joysticks, and I also don’t know how you connected it to your laptop. My best guess is if it shows up on driverstation it should show you what you need to do to get it. If it’s listed as an Axes, then you need to use .getRawAxis(number) or other function to get an axis. If shows up as a POV button, then you’ll have to check the docs for how to use those.
